sanskrit: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच | धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः | मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ||
transliteration: dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca | dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ | māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāścaiva kimakurvata sañjaya ||
translation_sivananda: Dhritarashtra said: What did the sons of Pandu and also my people do when they had assembled together, eager for battle on the holy plain of Kurukshetra, O Sanjaya?
translation_telugu: ధృతరాష్ట్రుడు పలికెను: ఓ సంజయా! ధర్మక్షేత్రమైన కురుక్షేత్రమునందు యుద్ధము చేయగోరిన నా వారు, పాండుపుత్రులు ఏమి చేసిరి?
modern_commentary: The Gita begins not with a statement, but with a question born of attachment and anxiety. The blind king Dhritarashtra asks about the fate of 'my people' versus the 'sons of Pandu.' This sets the stage for the central conflict, which is not just an external battle, but the internal battle of 'us vs. them,' ego, and attachment that every human being faces in the 'dharmakshetra' (field of righteousness) of their own life.

sanskrit: क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते। क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप॥
transliteration: klaibyaṁ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitattvayyupapadyate | kṣudraṁ hṛdayadaurbalyaṁ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa ||
translation_sivananda: Yield not to impotence, O Arjuna, it does not befit thee. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O scorcher of foes!
translation_telugu: పార్థా! భయమును పొందకుము, ఇది నీకు తగదు. ఓ శత్రువులను తపింపజేయువాడా! నీచమైన హృదయ దౌర్బల్యాన్ని విడిచిపెట్టి, యుద్ధానికి లెమ్ము.
modern_commentary: This is a direct call to action against despair. In modern life, when we feel overwhelmed and want to give up, this verse reminds us that succumbing to helplessness is beneath our true potential. It's a powerful command to shake off self-pity and stand up to face our challenges, not with aggression, but with inner strength and resolve.

sanskrit: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः। यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम्॥
transliteration: kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṁ dharmasammūḍhacetāḥ | yacchreyaḥ syānniścitaṁ brūhi tanme śiṣyaste'haṁ śādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam ||
translation_sivananda: My heart is overpowered by the taint of pity; my mind is confused as to duty. I ask Thee. Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Thy disciple. Instruct me, who has taken refuge in Thee.
translation_telugu: నా స్వభావము దీనత్వమనే దోషముచే కొట్టబడి, ధర్మము విషయంలో నా మనస్సు గందరగోళానికి గురైనది. నాకు ఏది నిశ్చితముగా శ్రేయస్కరమో దానిని చెప్పుము. నేను నీ శిష్యుడను, నిన్ను శరణు పొందిన నన్ను శాసించుము.
modern_commentary: This marks a crucial turning point. Arjuna, in his confusion, realizes the limitation of his own intellect. He moves from friendly debate to humble surrender, accepting the role of a disciple seeking guidance. This act of humility and surrender is what opens the door to receiving profound wisdom. In our own lives, acknowledging 'I don't know' and seeking guidance with an open heart is the first step toward true learning and growth.

sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे | गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः ||
transliteration: śrībhagavānuvāca | aśocyānanvaśocastvaṁ prajñāvādāṁśca bhāṣase | gatāsūnagatāsūṁśca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ ||
translation_sivananda: The Blessed Lord said: Thou hast grieved for those that should not be grieved for, yet thou speakest words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead.
translation_telugu: శ్రీభగవానుడు పలికెను: నీవు దుఃఖించకూడని వారి కోసము దుఃఖించుచున్నావు, అయిననూ జ్ఞానయుక్తమైన మాటలు మాట్లాడుచున్నావు. పండితులు మరణించిన వారి కొరకు గాని, జీవించియున్న వారి కొరకు గాని దుఃఖించరు.
modern_commentary: Krishna begins his teaching by pointing out the contradiction in Arjuna's thinking. Arjuna is speaking like a wise man but grieving like an ignorant one. The core teaching introduced here is that a truly wise person understands the nature of reality and therefore does not grieve for what is ultimately unchangeable and eternal. This sets the foundation for the upcoming lessons on the nature of the soul.

sanskrit: देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा। तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति॥
transliteration: dehino 'smin yathā dehe kaumāraṁ yauvanaṁ jarā | tathā dehāntaraprāptirdhīrastatra na muhyati ||
translation_sivananda: Just as in this body the embodied (soul) passes into childhood, youth and old age, so also does it pass into another body; the firm man does not grieve thereat.
translation_telugu: శరీరమునందు ఆత్మకు బాల్యము, యౌవనము, వృద్ధాప్యము ఎలా కలుగుచున్నవో, అదే విధముగా మరొక శరీరమును పొందుట జరుగును. ధీరుడైనవాడు దీనికి మోహము చెందడు.
modern_commentary: This verse offers a profound perspective on change and mortality. It teaches us to see life as a continuous journey of consciousness through different phases. Just as we don't mourn the passing of our youth, a wise person understands that the transition of the soul from one body to another is a natural process, helping alleviate the fear of death.

sanskrit: मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः। आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत॥
transliteration: mātrāsparśāstu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ | āgamāpāyino'nityāstāṁstitikṣasva bhārata ||
translation_sivananda: The contacts of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which cause heat and cold, pleasure and pain, have a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna.
translation_telugu: ఓ కౌంతేయా! ఇంద్రియములు, విషయముల సంయోగము వలన శీతోష్ణములు, సుఖదుఃఖములు కలుగును. అవి శాశ్వతమైనవి కావు, వచ్చి పోయేవి. ఓ భరతవంశీయుడా! వాటిని సహింపుము.
modern_commentary: This verse explains the nature of our sensory experiences. Everything we feel—hot, cold, joy, sorrow—arises from the interaction of our senses with the world. These feelings are temporary by nature. The path to inner stability lies not in chasing pleasure and avoiding pain, but in developing the resilience to endure both with a calm mind, knowing 'this too shall pass'.

sanskrit: यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ। समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते॥
transliteration: yaṁ hi na vyathayantyete puruṣaṁ puruṣarṣabha | samaduḥkhasukhaṁ dhīraṁ so'mṛtatvāya kalpate ||
translation_sivananda: That firm man whom surely these afflict not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.
translation_telugu: ఓ పురుషశ్రేష్ఠుడా! సుఖదుఃఖములను సమానముగా భావించే ఏ ధీరుడైన పురుషుడిని ఇవి కలత పెట్టవో, అతడు అమరత్వమును పొందుటకు అర్హుడు.
modern_commentary: This verse states the glorious result of cultivating resilience and equanimity. The person who is not tossed about by the waves of pleasure and pain, who remains steady through life's dualities, becomes fit for 'immortality'. This doesn't just mean living forever; it means realizing one's eternal nature, free from the suffering caused by the transient experiences of the world.

sanskrit: न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन् नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः। अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे॥
transliteration: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṁ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ | ajo nityaḥ śāśvato 'yaṁ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre ||
translation_sivananda: The Self is not born, nor does It die; coming into being and ceasing to be do not take place. It is unborn, eternal, permanent and primeval. The Self is not slain when the body is slain.
translation_telugu: ఈ ఆత్మ ఎప్పుడూ పుట్టేది కాదు, మరణించేది కాదు. ఇది పుట్టి మళ్ళీ ఉండేది కాదు. ఈ ఆత్మ పుట్టుక లేనిది, నిత్యమైనది, శాశ్వతమైనది, పురాతనమైనది. శరీరము చంపబడినప్పుడు ఇది చంపబడదు.
modern_commentary: This verse provides deep comfort by defining the nature of our true identity—the Self (Atman). It tells us that our core essence is beyond birth and death, permanent and unchanging. In a world where everything is temporary, this wisdom encourages us to anchor our identity in this eternal consciousness rather than our fleeting physical body or external circumstances.

sanskrit: वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि। तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णा न्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही॥
transliteration: vāsāṁsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro 'parāṇi | tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇānyanyāni saṁyāti navāni dehī ||
translation_sivananda: Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so also the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new.
translation_telugu: మనుష్యుడు పాతబడిన వస్త్రములను విడిచి కొత్త వస్త్రములను ఎలా ధరించునో, అదే విధముగా ఆత్మ జీర్ణమైన శరీరములను విడిచి కొత్త శరీరములలో ప్రవేశించును.
modern_commentary: This is a beautiful and simple analogy to help us understand the process of death and reincarnation. It demystifies death by comparing it to the simple act of changing clothes. The body is temporary apparel for the eternal soul. This perspective can reduce our attachment to the physical form and help us see life's transitions with less fear and more acceptance.

sanskrit: सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ। ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाప्स्यसि॥
transliteration: sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau | tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṁ pāpamavāpsyasi ||
translation_sivananda: Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat the same, engage thou in battle for the sake of battle; thus thou shalt not incur sin.
translation_telugu: సుఖదుఃఖములను, లాభనష్టములను, జయాపజయములను సమానముగా భావించి, అప్పుడు యుద్ధమునకు సిద్ధపడుము. ఈ విధముగా నీవు పాపమును పొందవు.
modern_commentary: This verse teaches the art of emotional resilience. Life will always present us with dualities: success and failure, happiness and sadness. The key to inner peace is to maintain a balanced mind amidst these fluctuations. By accepting both outcomes with equanimity and focusing on doing our duty, we free ourselves from the emotional rollercoaster and act with clarity and purpose.

sanskrit: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन। मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि॥
transliteration: karmaṇy-evādhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karma-phala-hetur bhūr mā te saṅgo 'stv akarmaṇi ||
translation_sivananda: Thy right is to work only, but never with its fruits; let not the fruits of action be thy motive, nor let thy attachment be to inaction.
translation_telugu: నీకు కర్మలు చేయుటయందే అధికారము కలదు, కాని వాటి ఫలములపై ఎప్పుడూ లేదు. కర్మ ఫలములకు కారణము నీవు కారాదు, అలాగని కర్మలు చేయకుండుట యందు ఆసక్తిని పెంచుకోరాదు.
modern_commentary: This famous verse guides us to find peace by focusing on our effort rather than the outcome. In our modern lives, we can control the quality of our work, but the final result is influenced by many factors. Becoming anxious about a specific outcome leads to stress. The wisdom here is to perform our duties with full dedication and gracefully accept whatever results may come.

sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते॥
transliteration: yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā dhanañjaya | siddhyasiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṁ yoga ucyate ||
translation_sivananda: Perform action, O Dhananjaya, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure. Evenness of mind is called Yoga.
translation_telugu: ఓ ధనుంజయా! ఆసక్తిని విడిచి, యోగమునందు నిలకడగా ఉండి, జయాపజయముల యందు సమభావముతో కర్మలను ఆచరించుము. ఈ సమత్వమే యోగమని చెప్పబడును.
modern_commentary: This verse provides a profound definition of Yoga: it is 'evenness of mind' or perfect equanimity. It instructs us to perform our actions while being centered in this state of balance, abandoning attachment to the outcomes. True yoga is not just physical postures; it is a state of mind where one remains stable and calm in both success and failure, acting with clarity and inner peace.

sanskrit: बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते। तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम्॥
transliteration: buddhiyukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte | tasmādyogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam ||
translation_sivananda: Endowed with wisdom (evenness of mind), one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote thyself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.
translation_telugu: సమబుద్ధి కలవాడు పుణ్యపాపములను రెండింటినీ ఈ లోకమునందే త్యజించును. కావున, యోగము కొరకు ప్రయత్నించుము. కర్మల యందలి నైపుణ్యమే యోగము.
modern_commentary: Here we get another beautiful definition: 'Yoga is skill in action.' This doesn't mean mere efficiency. It means performing actions with such wisdom and equanimity that you are not bound by their results, good or bad. It's the art of engaging with the world effectively and purposefully without getting entangled in the anxiety of outcomes. This skillfulness leads to freedom.

sanskrit: दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः। वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते॥
transliteration: duḥkheṣvanudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ | vītarāgabhayakrodhaḥ sthitadhīrmunirucyate ||
translation_sivananda: He whose mind is not shaken by adversity, who does not hanker after pleasures, and is free from attachment, fear and anger, is called a sage of steady wisdom.
translation_telugu: దుఃఖములు కలిగినప్పుడు కలత చెందని మనస్సు కలవాడు, సుఖముల యందు కోరిక లేనివాడు, అనురాగము, భయము, క్రోధములను విడిచినవాడు స్థిరమైన బుద్ధిగల ముని అని చెప్పబడును.
modern_commentary: This verse describes the state of a truly peaceful and wise person (a 'Sthitaprajna'). Such a person is not disturbed when things go wrong, nor do they desperately crave pleasant experiences. They are free from the grip of attachment, fear, and anger. This is not about being emotionless, but about being the master of one's emotions, maintaining a core of unshakeable inner calm.

sanskrit: यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्। नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता॥
transliteration: yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehastattatprāpya śubhāśubham | nābhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||
translation_sivananda: He who is everywhere without attachment, on meeting with anything good or evil, who neither rejoices nor hates, his wisdom is fixed.
translation_telugu: ఎవడైతే అన్నిటియందు ఆసక్తి లేకుండా, శుభము గాని అశుభము గాని పొందినప్పుడు, సంతోషించడో, ద్వేషించడో, అట్టివాని ప్రజ్ఞ స్థిరమైనది.
modern_commentary: This verse further defines a person of steady wisdom. Such a person has no clinging attachment to anything. When they encounter good fortune, they don't get overly excited or celebrate wildly. When they encounter misfortune, they don't hate it or despair. Their inner wisdom is so firmly established that they remain a calm, impartial witness to the unfolding events of life.

sanskrit: ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते। सङ्गात्संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते॥
transliteration: dhyāyato viṣayānpuṁsaḥ saṅgasteṣūpajāyate | saṅgātsaṁjāyate kāmaḥ kāmātkrodho 'bhijāyate ||
translation_sivananda: When a man thinks of the objects, attachment for them arises; from attachment desire is born; from desire anger arises.
translation_telugu: విషయములను గూర్చి ధ్యానించు పురుషునికి వాటియందు ఆసక్తి పుట్టును. ఆసక్తి వలన కోరిక పుట్టును. కోరిక నెరవేరనప్పుడు క్రోధము పుట్టును.
modern_commentary: This verse provides a brilliant psychological map of how suffering develops. It starts with a simple thought about an object or outcome. That thought leads to attachment. Attachment breeds desire or craving. When that desire is inevitably frustrated, it turns into anger. It teaches us the importance of mindfulness, of catching this negative chain reaction at its source.

sanskrit: क्रोधाद्भवति संमोहः संमोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः। स्मृतिभ्रंशाद्बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति॥
transliteration: krodhādbhavati saṁmohaḥ saṁmohātsmṛtivibhramaḥ | smṛtibhraṁśādbuddhināśo buddhināśātpraṇaśyati ||
translation_sivananda: From anger comes delusion; from delusion loss of memory; from loss of memory the destruction of discrimination; from destruction of discrimination, he perishes.
translation_telugu: క్రోధము వలన అవివేకము కలుగును. అవివేకము వలన జ్ఞాపకశక్తి నశించును. జ్ఞాపకశక్తి నశించుట వలన బుద్ధి నశించును. బుద్ధి నశించుట వలన అతడు నశించును.
modern_commentary: Continuing the previous verse, this shows the devastating domino effect of anger. Anger clouds our judgment ('delusion'), making us forget past lessons. This leads to a loss of our ability to make wise choices, which ultimately leads to our own downfall. It's a stark warning about the importance of managing anger for clear thinking and a successful life.

sanskrit: रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्। आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति॥
transliteration: rāgadveṣaviyuktaistu viṣayānindriyaiścaran | ātmavaśyairvidheyātmā prasādamadhigacchati ||
translation_sivananda: But the self-controlled man, moving amongst objects with senses under restraint, and free from attraction and repulsion, attains to peace.
translation_telugu: కానీ ఆత్మనిగ్రహం గలవాడు, రాగద్వేషములు లేనివాడై, తన వశమునందున్న ఇంద్రియములతో విషయములందు చరించుచు, ప్రశాంతతను పొందును.
modern_commentary: This verse provides the positive alternative to the path of desire and anger. It describes a person who engages with the world, but does so with their senses under complete control. They are free from the automatic pull of attraction (craving) and repulsion (aversion). Such a self-controlled individual, who is master of their own mind, attains a state of profound peace and clarity ('Prasada').

sanskrit: न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्। कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः॥
transliteration: na hi kaścitkṣaṇamapi jātu tiṣṭhatyakarmakṛt | kāryate hyavaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛtijairguṇaiḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Verily none can ever remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly by the qualities born of Nature.
translation_telugu: ఎవ్వడూ ఒక్క క్షణమైనా కర్మ చేయకుండా ఉండలేడు. ప్రకృతి నుండి పుట్టిన గుణములచే ప్రతివాడు నిస్సహాయుడై కర్మ చేయుటకు ప్రేరేపించబడును.
modern_commentary: This verse dispels the fantasy of escaping life by doing nothing. It states a fundamental truth: action is unavoidable. Even breathing or thinking is a form of action. We are constantly compelled to act by the forces of nature (the Gunas) within us. The wisdom here is that since we must act, our choice is not *whether* to act, but *how* to act—with what attitude and intention.

sanskrit: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः। तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर॥
transliteration: yajñārthātkarmaṇo'nyatra loko'yaṁ karmabandhanaḥ | tadarthaṁ karma kaunteya muktasaṅgaḥ samācara ||
translation_sivananda: The world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice; do thou, therefore, O son of Kunti, perform action for that sake (for sacrifice alone), free from attachment.
translation_telugu: యజ్ఞము కొరకు చేయు కర్మలు తప్ప ఇతర కర్మలచే ఈ లోకము బంధించబడియున్నది. కావున, ఓ కౌంతేయా! ఆసక్తిని విడిచి, యజ్ఞము కొరకే కర్మలను చక్కగా ఆచరించుము.
modern_commentary: This verse introduces the concept of 'Yajna' or sacrifice. It states that any action done for purely selfish reasons binds us in the cycle of karma. However, when we perform actions for a higher purpose, for the sake of service or 'sacrifice' without personal gain in mind, those actions liberate us. The key is to act selflessly, free from attachment, transforming our work into a sacred offering.

sanskrit: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः। स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते॥
transliteration: yadyadācarati śreṣṭhastattadevetaro janaḥ | sa yatpramāṇaṁ kurute lokastadanuvartate ||
translation_sivananda: Whatever a great man does, that other men also do; whatever he sets up as a standard, that the world follows.
translation_telugu: శ్రేష్ఠుడైనవాడు ఏది ఆచరించునో, దానినే ఇతరులు కూడా ఆచరింతురు. అతడు ఏది ప్రమాణముగా స్వీకరించునో, లోకము దానినే అనుసరించును.
modern_commentary: This verse highlights the immense responsibility that comes with leadership and influence. Whether you are a parent, a manager, a teacher, or just an older sibling, your actions set an example for others. People don't just listen to what you say; they watch what you do. It's a call to act with integrity and awareness, knowing that your behavior sets the standard for those who look up to you.

sanskrit: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः। अहंकारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते॥
transliteration: prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśaḥ | ahaṁkāravimūḍhātmā kartāhamiti manyate ||
translation_sivananda: All actions are wrought in all cases by the qualities of Nature only. He whose mind is deluded by egoism thinks, “I am the doer”.
translation_telugu: అన్ని కర్మలు అన్ని విధముల ప్రకృతి యొక్క గుణములచే చేయబడుచున్నవి. అహంకారముచే మోసగించబడిన ఆత్మ 'నేనే కర్తను' అని తలంచును.
modern_commentary: This verse is a powerful tool for developing humility and reducing stress. It teaches us that our actions and their outcomes are orchestrated by countless forces of nature, not just our own ego. When we mistakenly think 'I am the sole doer,' we take on the heavy burden of credit for success and blame for failure. By recognizing the role of larger forces, we can let go of this ego-centric view and act with less pressure.

sanskrit: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा। निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः॥
transliteration: mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi saṁnyasyādhyātmacetasā | nirāśīrnirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigatajvaraḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Renouncing all actions in Me, with the mind centred in the Self, getting rid of hope and selfishness, fight, free from (mental) fever.
translation_telugu: ఆధ్యాత్మిక చిత్తముతో సర్వ కర్మలను నాకు అర్పించి, ఆశను, మమకారమును విడిచి, శోకము లేనివాడవై యుద్ధము చేయుము.
modern_commentary: This verse provides a complete formula for peaceful action. 1) Dedicate all your actions to a higher purpose ('in Me'). 2) Keep your mind focused on your higher Self. 3) Let go of expectations and selfish desires. 4) Act without the 'fever' of anxiety, agitation, or fear. This is the essence of Karma Yoga: acting with full engagement but with complete inner freedom and tranquility.

sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः॥
transliteration: śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt | svadharme nidhanaṁ śreyaḥ paradharmo bhayāvahaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Better is one’s own duty, though destitute of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one’s own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.
translation_telugu: ఇతరుల ధర్మమును చక్కగా ఆచరించుట కంటె, గుణహీనమైనదైనను తన ధర్మమును ఆచరించుటయే శ్రేయస్కరము. తన ధర్మమునందు మరణమైనను శ్రేయస్కరమే, ఇతరుల ధర్మము భయంకరమైనది.
modern_commentary: This verse is a powerful message about authenticity. It is better to follow your own natural calling or duty (Svadharma), even if you do it imperfectly, than to perfectly imitate someone else's path. In a world of social media and constant comparison, this is a reminder to be true to your own nature and responsibilities. There is peace and rightness in performing the work that is uniquely yours.

sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः | महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम् ||
transliteration: śrībhagavānuvāca | kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajoguṇasamudbhavaḥ | mahāśano mahāpāpmā viddhyenamiha vairiṇam ||
translation_sivananda: The Blessed Lord said: It is desire, it is anger born of the quality of Rajas, all-consuming and all-sinful; know this as the foe here (in this world).
translation_telugu: శ్రీభగవానుడు పలికెను: ఇది రజోగుణము నుండి పుట్టిన కామము, ఇది క్రోధము. ఇది ఎంత తిన్నను తృప్తి చెందనిది, మహా పాపము. దీనిని ఈ లోకమునందు శత్రువుగా తెలిసికొనుము.
modern_commentary: In response to Arjuna's question about what compels a person to do wrong, Krishna gives a direct answer: it is desire ('kama') and anger ('krodha'). These arise from the quality of 'Rajas' (passion, activity). They are described as 'all-consuming' because they are never satisfied, always wanting more. This insatiable desire is identified as the true enemy we must conquer in our inner life.

sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्॥
transliteration: yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānirbhavati bhārata | abhyutthānamadharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛjāmyaham ||
translation_sivananda: Whenever there is a decline of righteousness, O Arjuna, and rise of unrighteousness, then I manifest Myself!
translation_telugu: ఓ అర్జునా! ఎప్పుడెప్పుడు ధర్మమునకు హాని కలుగునో, అధర్మము వృద్ధి చెందునో, అప్పుడు నేను నన్ను నేను సృష్టించుకొందును.
modern_commentary: This is a verse of profound hope and cosmic reassurance. It states that whenever virtue, justice, and righteousness (Dharma) decline and negativity rises, a divine force intervenes to restore balance. In our personal lives or in society, when things seem dark and unjust, this verse reminds us to have faith that the arc of the universe bends towards goodness.

sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे॥
transliteration: paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām | dharmasaṁsthāpanārthāya saṁbhavāmi yuge yuge ||
translation_sivananda: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.
translation_telugu: సాధువులను రక్షించుటకు, దుష్టులను నశింపజేయుటకు, ధర్మమును స్థాపించుటకు నేను యుగయుగములందు జన్మింతును.
modern_commentary: Continuing the previous thought, this verse clarifies the purpose of divine intervention: to protect the virtuous, to overcome destructive forces, and to re-establish a foundation of righteousness. This can be interpreted not just as a literal incarnation, but as the timeless principle that goodness and constructive forces will always rise to defend, protect, and ultimately re-establish order and harmony.

sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः॥
transliteration: ye yathā māṁ prapadyante tāṁstathaiva bhajāmyaham | mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: In whatever way men approach Me, even so do I reward them; My path do men tread in all ways, O Arjuna.
translation_telugu: ఓ పార్థా! మానవులు నన్ను ఏ విధముగా ఆశ్రయించెదరో, నేను వారిని ఆ విధముగానే అనుగ్రహింతును. మానవులు అన్ని విధముల నా మార్గమునే అనుసరించుచున్నారు.
modern_commentary: This is a profound statement of spiritual inclusivity. It declares that the Divine responds to each person according to the nature of their approach. It affirms that all spiritual paths ultimately lead to the same goal. This verse promotes tolerance and respect for different traditions and ways of thinking, recognizing that everyone is, in their own way, treading the path toward the same ultimate reality.

sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः। स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्॥
transliteration: karmaṇyakarma yaḥ paśyedakarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ | sa buddhimānmanuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsnakarmakṛt ||
translation_sivananda: He who sees inaction in action, and action in inaction, is wise among men; he is a Yogi and a performer of all actions.
translation_telugu: కర్మ యందు అకర్మను, అకర్మ యందు కర్మను ఎవడు చూచునో, అతడే మనుష్యులలో బుద్ధిమంతుడు. అతడే యోగి మరియు సర్వ కర్మలను చేసినవాడు.
modern_commentary: This paradoxical verse contains a deep truth. To see 'inaction in action' means to act with full engagement but without any selfish desire or attachment, thus being free from karmic bondage. To see 'action in inaction' means recognizing that even in stillness, the mind and body are active. The wise person understands this dynamic, acts with inner stillness, and remains peaceful and unattached while performing all their duties in the world.

sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः॥
transliteration: tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā | upadekṣyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninastattvadarśinaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Know that by long prostration, by question and by service, the wise who have realised the Truth will instruct thee in (that) knowledge.
translation_telugu: వినయముతో నమస్కరించి, ప్రశ్నలు అడిగి, సేవ చేసి దానిని తెలిసికొనుము. తత్త్వమును దర్శించిన జ్ఞానులు నీకు ఆ జ్ఞానమును ఉపదేశించెదరు.
modern_commentary: This verse outlines the proper way to approach a teacher to gain profound wisdom. It requires three things: 1) 'Pranipata' - Humility and respect, an attitude of being open to learning. 2) 'Pariprashna' - Intelligent and sincere questioning to remove doubts. 3) 'Seva' - Service, which helps to build a relationship and show one's earnestness. When these conditions are met, the wise are able to effectively transmit their knowledge.

sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते। तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति॥
transliteration: na hi jñānena sadṛśaṁ pavitramiha vidyate | tatsvayaṁ yogasaṁsiddhaḥ kālenātmani vindati ||
translation_sivananda: Verily there is no purifier in this world like knowledge. He who is perfected in Yoga finds it in the Self in due course of time.
translation_telugu: నిజముగా ఈ లోకమునందు జ్ఞానముతో సమానమైన పవిత్రమైనది ఏదీ లేదు. యోగమునందు సిద్ధిని పొందినవాడు కాలక్రమేణా దానిని తన ఆత్మయందే పొందును.
modern_commentary: This verse extols the supreme power of true knowledge (Jnana). It is described as the ultimate purifier, capable of cleansing the mind of all ignorance and negativity. This isn't just book learning; it is the direct experience of one's own true Self. The verse assures us that this profound knowledge is not something to be acquired from the outside, but is found within oneself through dedicated spiritual practice (Yoga) over time.

sanskrit: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
transliteration: śraddhāvāllabhate jñānaṁ tatparaḥ saṁyatendriyaḥ | jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śāntimacireṇādhigacchati ||
translation_sivananda: The man who is full of faith, who is devoted to it, and who has subdued the senses, obtains (this) knowledge; and having obtained knowledge, he goes ere long to the supreme peace.
translation_telugu: శ్రద్ధగలవాడు, దానియందు ఆసక్తిగలవాడు, ఇంద్రియములను జయించినవాడు జ్ఞానమును పొందును. జ్ఞానమును పొందిన వెంటనే అతడు పరమశాంతిని పొందును.
modern_commentary: This verse outlines the pathway to wisdom and peace. It requires three things: 'Shraddha' or faith in the path and the teachings; dedication and focus on that path; and control over one's senses so as not to be constantly distracted. When these three are present, knowledge arises, and this true knowledge isn't just intellectual—it leads directly to a state of profound, supreme peace.

sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः। सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते॥
transliteration: yogayukto viśuddhātmā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ | sarvabhūtātmabhūtātmā kurvannapi na lipyate ||
translation_sivananda: He who is devoted to the path of action, whose mind is pure, who has conquered the self, who has subdued his senses, who realises his own Self as the Self in all beings, though acting, is not tainted.
translation_telugu: యోగముతో కూడినవాడు, శుద్ధమైన ఆత్మ గలవాడు, ఆత్మను జయించినవాడు, ఇంద్రియములను జయించినవాడు, తన ఆత్మనే సర్వభూతముల ఆత్మగా చూచువాడు, కర్మలు చేసినను, వాటిచే అంటబడడు.
modern_commentary: This verse describes the state of a perfect Karma Yogi. Such a person has a pure mind, has conquered their lower self, and has their senses under control. Most importantly, they see their own Self as the Self in all beings. Because of this vision of oneness and inner purity, they can act dynamically in the world without being tainted or bound by their actions. Their actions flow from a place of unity, not from selfish desire.

sanskrit: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः। लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा॥
transliteration: brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā ||
translation_sivananda: He who performs actions, abandoning attachment, resigning them to Brahman (the Absolute), is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus leaf is not tainted by water.
translation_telugu: ఎవడైతే ఆసక్తిని విడిచి, కర్మలను బ్రహ్మమునకు అర్పించి చేయునో, అతడు తామరాకు నీటిచే అంటబడనట్లు, పాపముచే అంటబడడు.
modern_commentary: This verse uses a powerful and famous analogy. Just as a lotus leaf rests on the water but is never wetted by it, a person who acts with detachment is untouched by the karmic results of their actions. The key is to dedicate one's actions to a higher purpose ('Brahman') and abandon selfish attachment. This allows one to live fully engaged in the world while maintaining a state of inner purity and freedom.

sanskrit: विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि। शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः॥
transliteration: vidyāvinayasampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini | śuni caiva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ samadarśinaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Sages look with an equal eye on a Brahmin endowed with learning and humility, on a cow, on an elephant, and even on a dog or an outcaste.
translation_telugu: జ్ఞానులు విద్య మరియు వినయము గల బ్రాహ్మణుని యందు, ఆవునందు, ఏనుగునందు, కుక్కయందు మరియు చండాలుని యందు సమదృష్టి కలిగియుందురు.
modern_commentary: This verse describes the vision of a truly wise person. They see the same divine spark, the same essential Self, in every living being—from the most learned scholar to an animal to a person considered an outcast. This is the ultimate expression of equality and oneness. It challenges us to look past external labels and differences and to cultivate a vision that recognizes the shared divinity in all of creation.

sanskrit: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते। आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः॥
transliteration: ye hi saṁsparśajā bhogā duḥkhayonaya eva te | ādyantavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: The enjoyments that are born of contacts are only generators of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O son of Kunti. The wise do not rejoice in them.
translation_telugu: ఇంద్రియ విషయ సంయోగము వలన కలిగే భోగములు దుఃఖమునకే కారణములు, ఓ కౌంతేయా! అవి ఆది అంతము కలవి. వివేకి వాటియందు ఆనందించడు.
modern_commentary: This verse offers a critical insight into the nature of worldly pleasure. Any happiness that depends on external contact—be it through sight, sound, or touch—is inherently temporary. Because it has a beginning, it must have an end, and its passing often leads to pain or craving for more. A wise person understands this cycle and therefore doesn't seek lasting joy in fleeting pleasures, instead looking for a more stable, inner source of contentment.

sanskrit: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम्। सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति॥
transliteration: bhoktāraṁ yajñatapasāṁ sarvalokamaheśvaram | suhṛdaṁ sarvabhūtānāṁ jñātvā māṁ śāntimṛcchati ||
translation_sivananda: He who knows Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the great Lord of all the worlds and the friend of all beings, attains to peace.
translation_telugu: యజ్ఞతపస్సులను అనుభవించువానిగా, సర్వలోకములకు మహేశ్వరునిగా, సర్వభూతములకు మిత్రునిగా నన్ను తెలిసికొని, శాంతిని పొందును.
modern_commentary: This verse provides a direct 'formula for peace.' It says that peace is attained by knowing and internalizing three truths: 1) That a higher power is the ultimate enjoyer of all our efforts (sacrifices and austerities). 2) That this power is the great Lord governing all worlds. 3) That this same supreme power is the intimate, loving friend of every single being. Understanding this removes the ego, provides a sense of security, and establishes a feeling of universal friendship, leading to profound peace.

sanskrit: उद्धरेदात्मनात्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्। आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः॥
transliteration: uddhared ātmanātmānaṁ nātmānam avasādayet | ātmaiva hy ātmano bandhur ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Let a man lift himself by his own Self alone; let him not lower himself, for the Self alone is the friend of the self, and the Self alone is the enemy of the self.
translation_telugu: మానవుడు తనను తానే ఉద్ధరించుకోవాలి, తనను తాను అధోగతికి పడద్రోయకూడదు. తనకు తానే బంధువు, తనకు తానే శత్రువు.
modern_commentary: This powerful verse is a call for self-empowerment and personal responsibility. It teaches that we are our own greatest ally and our own worst enemy. Our 'higher Self'—our wisdom, discipline, and conscience—can lift us up. Our 'lower self'—our negative thoughts, bad habits, and untrained mind—can drag us down. The key to overcoming our struggles lies within our own ability to manage our mind and choose to be our own best friend.

sanskrit: बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः। अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत्॥
transliteration: bandhurātmātmanastasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ | anātmanastu śatrutve vartetātmaiva śatruvat ||
translation_sivananda: The Self is the friend of the self for him who has conquered himself by the Self, but to the unconquered self, this self is inimical, like a foe.
translation_telugu: ఎవనిచే ఆత్మ ఆత్మచే జయించబడినదో, వానికి ఆత్మయే బంధువు. జయింపబడని ఆత్మకు, ఆత్మయే శత్రువు వలె ప్రవర్తించును.
modern_commentary: Continuing the previous verse, this clarifies who is a friend and who is an enemy to oneself. For a person who has achieved self-mastery—who has conquered their impulses and negative thoughts with their higher wisdom—their own Self becomes their greatest friend and supporter. But for someone who has not conquered their lower nature, their own mind and impulses act like an external enemy, constantly creating conflict and suffering.

sanskrit: सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु। साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते॥
transliteration: suhṛnmitrāryudāsīnamadhyasthadveṣyabandhuṣu | sādhuṣvapi ca pāpeṣu samabuddhirviśiṣyate ||
translation_sivananda: He who is of the same mind to the good-hearted, friends, enemies, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, relatives, the righteous and the unrighteous, excels.
translation_telugu: శ్రేయోభిలాషుల యందు, మిత్రుల యందు, శత్రువుల యందు, తటస్థుల యందు, మధ్యస్థుల యందు, ద్వేషించదగినవారి యందు, బంధువుల యందు, పుణ్యాత్ముల యందు మరియు పాపాత్ముల యందు సమబుద్ధి కలవాడు శ్రేష్ఠుడు.
modern_commentary: This verse describes an advanced state of wisdom and equanimity in our relationships. A truly evolved person maintains a balanced and impartial mind towards everyone, regardless of their label: friend, enemy, saint, or sinner. This doesn't mean condoning harmful actions, but rather understanding the shared human condition and not letting personal preference or prejudice cloud one's inner peace and judgment.

sanskrit: युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु। युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा॥
transliteration: yuktāhāravihārasya yuktaceṣṭasya karmasu | yuktasvapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkhahā ||
translation_sivananda: Yoga becomes the destroyer of pain for him who is moderate in eating and recreation, who is moderate in his exertion in actions, who is moderate in sleep and wakefulness.
translation_telugu: మితమైన ఆహార విహారములు కలవానికి, కర్మల యందు మితమైన ప్రయత్నము కలవానికి, మితమైన నిద్ర మరియు మెలకువ కలవానికి, యోగము దుఃఖమును పోగొట్టునది అగును.
modern_commentary: This verse champions the 'middle path' and is a timeless piece of advice for a healthy life. It states that Yoga (as a state of being free from pain and suffering) is achieved by those who are moderate and balanced in everything they do: eating, recreation, work, sleep, and wakefulness. It warns against extremes, advocating for a sustainable, balanced lifestyle as the foundation for spiritual and mental well-being.

sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि। ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः॥
transliteration: sarvabhūtasthamātmānaṁ sarvabhūtāni cātmani | īkṣate yogayuktātmā sarvatra samadarśanaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: With the mind harmonised by Yoga he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.
translation_telugu: యోగముతో కూడిన మనస్సు గలవాడు, సర్వత్ర సమదృష్టి కలవాడై, ఆత్మను సర్వభూతముల యందు, సర్వభూతములను ఆత్మ యందు చూచును.
modern_commentary: This is the ultimate fruit of Yoga: the vision of oneness. A person whose mind is steady and harmonized sees their own Self in every being, and sees all beings as existing within their own Self. The sense of separation between 'me' and 'you' dissolves. This perception is the very foundation of true empathy and universal love, as harming another is seen as harming oneself.

sanskrit: चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद्दृढम्। तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम्॥
transliteration: cañcalaṁ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavaddṛḍham | tasyāhaṁ nigrahaṁ manye vāyoriva suduṣkaram ||
translation_sivananda: The mind is restless, turbulent, obstinate and strong, O Krishna, and I think to control it is as difficult as controlling the wind.
translation_telugu: ఓ కృష్ణా! మనస్సు చంచలమైనది, కలత పెట్టేది, బలమైనది, దృఢమైనది. దానిని నిగ్రహించుట గాలిని నిరోధించుట వలె చాలా కష్టమని నేను భావిస్తున్నాను.
modern_commentary: This verse is incredibly relatable for anyone who has ever tried to meditate or focus their mind. Arjuna expresses a universal human frustration: the mind is incredibly restless and difficult to control, like trying to tame the wind. This verse validates our struggle, reassuring us that this is a recognized and difficult challenge, not a personal failure.

sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते | न हि कल्याणकृत्कश्चिद्दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति ||
transliteration: śrībhagavānuvāca | pārtha naiveha nāmutra vināśastasya vidyate | na hi kalyāṇakṛtkaściddurgatiṁ tāta gacchati ||
translation_sivananda: The Blessed Lord said: O Arjuna, neither in this world, nor in the next is there destruction for him; none, verily, who does good, O My son, ever comes to grief.
translation_telugu: శ్రీభగవానుడు పలికెను: ఓ పార్థా! వానికి ఈ లోకమునందు గాని, పరలోకమునందు గాని నాశనము లేదు. ఓ నాయనా! మంచి పనులు చేయువాడెవ్వడూ దుర్గతిని పొందడు.
modern_commentary: This verse provides immense reassurance for anyone on a path of self-improvement or spirituality. Arjuna worries about what happens if one tries but fails to achieve the goal in this lifetime. Krishna promises that no sincere effort towards doing good is ever wasted. A person who strives for goodness will never meet a sorrowful end, either in this life or the next. Every step taken on the right path counts.

sanskrit: मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये। यततामपि सिद्धानां कश्चिन्मां वेत्ति तत्त्वतः॥
transliteration: manuṣyāṇāṁ sahasreṣu kaścidyatati siddhaye | yatatāmapi siddhānāṁ kaścinmāṁ vetti tattvataḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Among thousands of men, one perchance strives for perfection; even among those who strive and are perfect, only one perchance knows Me in truth.
translation_telugu: వేలకొలది మనుష్యులలో ఒకానొకడు మాత్రమే సిద్ధి కొరకు ప్రయత్నించును. అట్లు ప్రయత్నించి సిద్ధిని పొందిన వారిలో కూడా, ఒకానొకడు మాత్రమే నన్ను యథార్థముగా తెలిసికొనును.
modern_commentary: This verse puts the spiritual journey into perspective, highlighting its difficulty and rarity. It states that only one in thousands even begins to strive for perfection, and even among those who succeed in their striving, only a rare few come to know the ultimate truth in its entirety. This is not meant to be discouraging, but to instill a sense of reverence and appreciation for the profoundness of the path and the preciousness of true spiritual knowledge.

sanskrit: मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय। मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव॥
transliteration: mattaḥ parataraṁ nānyatkiñcidasti dhanañjaya | mayi sarvamidaṁ protaṁ sūtre maṇigaṇā iva ||
translation_sivananda: There is nothing whatsoever higher than Me, O Dhananjaya. All this is strung on Me, as clusters of gems on a string.
translation_telugu: ఓ ధనుంజయా! నా కంటె శ్రేష్ఠమైనది ఏదీ లేదు. దారమునందు మణులు కూర్చబడినట్లు, ఈ సర్వము నా యందు కూర్చబడియున్నది.
modern_commentary: This verse uses a beautiful metaphor to explain the interconnectedness of the universe. It describes a single, supreme consciousness (God) as the thread that runs through and holds together everything in existence, just as a string holds together the individual gems of a necklace. Each of us, and everything we see, is a unique 'gem,' but we are all connected by and dependent on that same underlying thread of divine reality.

sanskrit: दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया। मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते॥
transliteration: daivī hyeṣā guṇamayī mama māyā duratyayā | māmeva ye prapadyante māyāmetāṁ taranti te ||
translation_sivananda: Verily, this divine illusion of Mine, made up of the qualities, is difficult to cross over; those who take refuge in Me alone cross over this illusion.
translation_telugu: గుణమయమైన నా ఈ దైవిక మాయను దాటుట చాలా కష్టము. ఎవరైతే నన్నే శరణు పొందుతారో, వారు ఈ మాయను దాటగలరు.
modern_commentary: This verse explains why the world can be so confusing and difficult to navigate. It is veiled by 'Maya,' a divine illusion created by the interplay of the three Gunas. This illusion is incredibly powerful and hard to see through on our own. However, the verse provides the solution: by taking refuge in and surrendering to the ultimate reality (God), one can receive the grace to cross over this illusion and see things as they truly are.

sanskrit: गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत्। प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम्॥
transliteration: gatirbhartā prabhuḥ sākṣī nivāsaḥ śaraṇaṁ suhṛt | prabhavaḥ pralayaḥ sthānaṁ nidhānaṁ bījamavyayam ||
translation_sivananda: I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house and the seed which is imperishable.
translation_telugu: నేనే గమ్యమును, భర్తను, ప్రభువును, సాక్షిని, నివాసమును, శరణమును, మిత్రుడను. నేనే సృష్టి, ప్రళయము, ఆధారము, నిధానము, మరియు నాశరహితమైన బీజమును.
modern_commentary: This verse provides a comprehensive and comforting description of the Divine. It lists multiple roles: the ultimate goal of our journey, the sustainer who supports us, the master, the silent witness to all our actions, our home, our shelter in times of trouble, and our dearest friend. It is also the source, the end, and the foundation of everything. Meditating on these attributes can help build a deep and multifaceted relationship with a higher power.

sanskrit: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते। तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम्॥
transliteration: ananyāścintayanto māṁ ye janāḥ paryupāsate | teṣāṁ nityābhiyuktānāṁ yogakṣemaṁ vahāmyaham ||
translation_sivananda: To those men who worship Me alone, thinking of no other, to those ever-united, I secure what is not already possessed and preserve what they already possess.
translation_telugu: ఇతర చింతనలు లేకుండా నన్నే ధ్యానిస్తూ, ఆరాధించే జనులకు, నిరంతరం నాతో ఐక్యమైయున్న వారి యోగక్షేమములను నేను వహిస్తాను.
modern_commentary: This verse offers a promise of security and care for those who live with unwavering faith and focus on a higher purpose. It suggests that when we dedicate our thoughts and actions to a noble ideal or the Divine, and cease our anxious striving for personal gain, our well-being is taken care of. It encourages us to let go of the constant worry about 'what I need' and 'what I have,' and to trust that by focusing on our spiritual path, our material needs will be met.

sanskrit: पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति। तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि प्रयतात्मनः॥
transliteration: patraṁ puṣpaṁ phalaṁ toyaṁ yo me bhaktyā prayacchati | tadahaṁ bhaktyupahṛtamaśnāmi prayatātmanaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit or a little water—that, so offered devotedly by the pure-minded, I accept.
translation_telugu: ఎవరైతే భక్తితో నాకు ఒక ఆకును గాని, పువ్వును గాని, పండును గాని, కొద్దిగా నీటిని గాని సమర్పిస్తారో, దానిని నేను శుద్ధమైన మనస్సు గల వానిచే భక్తితో సమర్పించబడిన దానిని స్వీకరిస్తాను.
modern_commentary: This beautiful verse emphasizes that the sincerity of our intention matters far more than the material value of our offering. Whether in our relationships, work, or spiritual practice, a small act done with great love and pure intention is more valuable than a grand gesture done for show. It teaches that the Divine, or the universe, responds not to the size of the gift, but to the depth of the devotion behind it.

sanskrit: यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत्। यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम्॥
transliteration: yatkaroṣi yadaśnāsi yajjuhosi dadāsi yat | yattapasyasi kaunteya tatkuruṣva madarpaṇam ||
translation_sivananda: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever you practise as austerity, O son of Kunti, do it as an offering unto Me.
translation_telugu: ఓ కౌంతేయా! నీవు ఏది చేసినా, ఏది తిన్నా, ఏది హోమము చేసినా, ఏది దానము చేసినా, ఏ తపస్సు చేసినా, దానిని నాకు అర్పణముగా చేయుము.
modern_commentary: This verse provides a powerful technique for making one's entire life a spiritual practice. It suggests that any action—from the mundane act of eating to your daily work—can be transformed into a sacred offering by dedicating it to a higher purpose or the Divine. This mindset elevates everyday life, turning routine tasks into acts of mindful devotion and connecting everything you do to your spiritual goal.

sanskrit: समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः। ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम्॥
transliteration: samo'haṁ sarvabhūteṣu na me dveṣyo'sti na priyaḥ | ye bhajanti tu māṁ bhaktyā mayi te teṣu cāpyaham ||
translation_sivananda: The same am I to all beings; there is none hateful or dear to Me. But those who worship Me with devotion are in Me and I am also in them.
translation_telugu: నేను సర్వభూతముల యందు సమముగా నున్నాను. నాకు ద్వేషించదగినవాడు గాని, ప్రియుడు గాని లేడు. కానీ ఎవరైతే నన్ను భక్తితో సేవించెదరో, వారు నా యందు, నేను వారి యందు ఉన్నాను.
modern_commentary: The Divine is described as being completely impartial, like the sun that shines equally on everyone, without preference or prejudice. However, a special relationship is formed with those who approach with devotion. It's not that God loves them more, but that their devotion opens them up to experience the divine presence more intimately. Just as a mirror facing the sun reflects it perfectly, a heart turned towards the Divine with devotion experiences a reciprocal presence.

sanskrit: अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते। इति मत्वा भजन्ते मां बुधा भावसमन्विताः॥
transliteration: ahaṁ sarvasya prabhavo mattaḥ sarvaṁ pravartate | iti matvā bhajante māṁ budhā bhāvasamanvitāḥ ||
translation_sivananda: I am the source of all; from Me everything evolves; understanding thus, the wise, endowed with meditation, worship Me.
translation_telugu: నేను సర్వమునకు మూలమును, నా నుండియే సర్వము ప్రవర్తిల్లుచున్నది. ఈ విధముగా తెలిసికొని, వివేకులు, భావముతో కూడినవారై నన్ను భజింతురు.
modern_commentary: This verse states that the ultimate reality is the source from which the entire universe originates and evolves. True wisdom lies in understanding this fundamental truth. When one recognizes this single source behind all of creation's diversity, they are naturally filled with a sense of awe and devotion, and they begin to worship or revere that source in all its forms.

sanskrit: तेषां सततयुक्तानां भजतां प्रीतिपूर्वकम्। ददामि बुद्धियोगं तं येन मामुपयान्ति ते॥
transliteration: teṣāṁ satatayuktānāṁ bhajatāṁ prītipūrvakam | dadāmi buddhiyogaṁ taṁ yena māmupayānti te ||
translation_sivananda: To them, ever steadfast and serving Me with love, I give the Yoga of discrimination by which they come to Me.
translation_telugu: నిరంతరం నాతో ఐక్యమై, ప్రేమతో నన్ను సేవించే వారికి, వారు నన్ను పొందుటకు అవసరమైన బుద్ధి యోగమును నేను ప్రసాదిస్తాను.
modern_commentary: This verse is a promise of divine guidance. It says that for those who are consistently dedicated and act with a loving heart towards their spiritual goal, the universe itself provides the necessary wisdom and understanding ('Buddhi Yoga') to navigate life's challenges and move closer to that goal. It implies that when our intention is pure and our effort is sincere, clarity and insight are given to us.

sanskrit: तेषामेवानुकम्पार्थमहमज्ञानजं तमः। नाशयाम्यात्मभावस्थो ज्ञानदीपेन भास्वता॥
transliteration: teṣāmevānukampārthamahamajñānajaṁ tamaḥ | nāśayāmyātmabhāvastho jñānadīpena bhāsvatā ||
translation_sivananda: Out of mere compassion for them, I, dwelling in their hearts, destroy the darkness born of ignorance by the luminous lamp of knowledge.
translation_telugu: వారిపై కేవలం కరుణతో, వారి హృదయములందు నివసించి, అజ్ఞానము నుండి పుట్టిన చీకటిని, ప్రకాశవంతమైన జ్ఞానమనే దీపముచే నేను నశింపజేయుదును.
modern_commentary: This verse explains the mechanism of divine grace. Out of pure compassion, the divine consciousness, which already dwells within our hearts, destroys the darkness of our ignorance. It does this not through external force, but by lighting the 'luminous lamp of knowledge' within us. This suggests that enlightenment is not something we create, but a revelation that occurs when our inner darkness is dispelled by this inner light.

sanskrit: दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता। यदि भाः सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मनः॥
transliteration: divi sūryasahasrasya bhavedyugapadutthitā | yadi bhāḥ sadṛśī sā syādbhāsastasya mahātmanaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: If the splendour of a thousand suns were to blaze out at once in the sky, that would be like the splendour of that mighty Being.
translation_telugu: ఆకాశమునందు వెయ్యి సూర్యుల కాంతి ఒక్కసారిగా ఉదయించినచో, ఆ కాంతి ఆ మహాత్ముని తేజస్సుకు సమానము కావచ్చును.
modern_commentary: This verse attempts to describe the indescribable—the sheer vastness and splendor of the cosmic, universal consciousness. The imagery of a thousand suns exploding at once is used to convey a brilliance and power that is beyond human comprehension. It serves to humble the ego and fill the heart with a sense of awe at the magnificent, powerful universe of which we are a tiny part.

sanskrit: स्थाने हृषीकेश तव प्रकीर्त्या जगत्प्रहृष्यत्यनुरज्यते च। रक्षांसि भीतानि दिशो द्रवन्ति सर्वे नमस्यन्ति च सिद्धसङ्घाः॥
transliteration: sthāne hṛṣīkeśa tava prakīrtyā jagatprahṛṣyatyanurajyate ca | rakṣāṁsi bhītāni diśo dravanti sarve namasyanti ca siddhasaṅghāḥ ||
translation_sivananda: It is meet, O Hrishikesa, that the world rejoices and delights in Thy praise; the demons fly in fear to all quarters and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to Thee.
translation_telugu: ఓ హృషీకేశా! నీ కీర్తిచే జగత్తు హర్షించి, అనురాగము చెందుట యుక్తమే. రాక్షసులు భయపడి అన్ని దిక్కులకు పారిపోవుచున్నారు, మరియు సిద్ధుల సమూహములు నీకు నమస్కరించుచున్నవి.
modern_commentary: This verse captures the natural human reaction to witnessing something truly divine and magnificent. Upon seeing the Universal Form, Arjuna observes that the forces of good (the world, the perfected ones) rejoice and bow in reverence, while the forces of negativity (demons) are scattered in fear. It illustrates the principle that the presence of overwhelming goodness and truth naturally brings joy to the virtuous and disperses darkness.

sanskrit: भक्त्या त्वनन्यया शक्य अहमेवंविधोऽर्जुन। ज्ञातुं द्रष्टुं च तत्त्वेन प्रवेष्टुं च परन्तप॥
transliteration: bhaktyā tvananyayā śakya ahamevaṁvidho'rjuna | jñātuṁ draṣṭuṁ ca tattvena praveṣṭuṁ ca parantapa ||
translation_sivananda: But by single-minded devotion can I, of this form, be known and seen in reality and also entered into, O scorcher of foes.
translation_telugu: కానీ, ఓ అర్జునా! అనన్యమైన భక్తి చేత మాత్రమే ఈ రూపము గల నన్ను యథార్థముగా తెలిసికొనుటకు, చూచుటకు, మరియు నాలో ప్రవేశించుటకు సాధ్యమగును.
modern_commentary: After revealing the awe-inspiring Universal Form, Krishna explains that this profound reality cannot be understood through intellect, ritual, or austerity alone. It can only be truly known, seen, and entered into through single-minded, unwavering devotion (Bhakti). This highlights that a heart full of love and faith is the key to unlocking the deepest spiritual truths, more so than a mind full of intellectual knowledge.

sanskrit: क्लेशोऽधिकतरस्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम्। अव्यक्ता हि गतिर्दुःखं देहवद्भिरवाప्यते॥
transliteration: kleśo'dhikatarasteṣāmavyaktāsaktacetasām | avyaktā hi gatirduḥkhaṁ dehavadbhiravāpyate ||
translation_sivananda: Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the Unmanifested; for the goal of the Unmanifested is very hard for the embodied to reach.
translation_telugu: అవ్యక్తమునందు (నిరాకారమునందు) ఆసక్తి గలవారికి కష్టము అధికము. ఎందుకనగా, దేహధారులకు అవ్యక్త మార్గము దుఃఖముతో కూడియుండును.
modern_commentary: This verse offers practical advice on spiritual paths. It acknowledges that for most people who are embodied beings, focusing on an abstract, formless, unmanifested concept of God is extremely difficult and can lead to more struggle. For this reason, paths involving devotion to a form, a name, or a tangible ideal are often easier and more direct for the human mind and heart to connect with.

sanskrit: अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च। निर्ममो निरहंकारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी॥
transliteration: adveṣṭā sarvabhūtānāṁ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca | nirmamo nirahaṁkāraḥ samaduḥkhasukhaḥ kṣamī ||
translation_sivananda: He who hates no creature, who is friendly and compassionate to all, who is free from attachment and egoism, balanced in pleasure and pain, and forgiving,
translation_telugu: సర్వభూతముల యందు ద్వేషము లేనివాడు, స్నేహభావము, కరుణ గలవాడు, మమకారము, అహంకారము లేనివాడు, సుఖదుఃఖముల యందు సమముగా నుండువాడు, క్షమించువాడు,
modern_commentary: This verse begins a description of the qualities of a person who is dearly loved by the Divine. It is a practical guide to ethical and spiritual living. The ideal person feels no ill-will, is genuinely friendly and compassionate, is not possessive ('mine-ness'), is free from ego, remains balanced in life's ups and downs, and is always ready to forgive. These are universal virtues that lead to a peaceful life.

sanskrit: सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः। मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः॥
transliteration: santuṣṭaḥ satataṁ yogī yatātmā dṛḍhaniścayaḥ | mayyarpitamanobuddhiryo madbhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessed of firm conviction, with mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devotee, is dear to Me.
translation_telugu: నిరంతరం సంతృప్తిగా ఉండేవాడు, యోగి, ఆత్మనిగ్రహం కలవాడు, దృఢ నిశ్చయం కలవాడు, మనస్సును, బుద్ధిని నాకు అర్పించినవాడు అయిన నా భక్తుడు నాకు ప్రియుడు.
modern_commentary: Continuing the list of cherished qualities, this verse highlights inner states. The ideal devotee is always content with what they have, steady in their spiritual practice, master of their own self, and holds a firm conviction in their path. Crucially, their mind and intellect are dedicated to a higher purpose. This speaks to a life of contentment, discipline, and unwavering focus.

sanskrit: अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम्। आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः॥
transliteration: amānitvamadambhitvamahiṁsā kṣāntirārjavam | ācāryopāsanaṁ śaucaṁ sthairyamātmavinigrahaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service to the teacher, purity, steadfastness, self-control.
translation_telugu: వినయము, గర్వము లేకుండుట, అహింస, క్షమ, సూటిదనము, గురువును సేవించుట, శుచిత్వము, స్థిరత్వము, ఆత్మనిగ్రహము.
modern_commentary: This begins a list of qualities that constitute true knowledge or wisdom. Notice that 'knowledge' here is not about accumulating facts, but about cultivating virtues. Humility, honesty, non-violence, forgiveness, integrity, cleanliness (of mind and body), stability, and self-control are presented as the very substance of wisdom. To be wise is to embody these qualities.

sanskrit: उपद्रष्टानुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः। परमात्मेति चाप्युक्तो देहेऽस्मिन्पुरुषः परः॥
transliteration: upadraṣṭānumantā ca bhartā bhoktā maheśvaraḥ | paramātmeti cāpyukto dehe'sminpuruṣaḥ paraḥ ||
translation_sivananda: The Supreme Person in this body is also called the spectator, the permitter, the supporter, the enjoyer, the great Lord and the Supreme Self.
translation_telugu: ఈ దేహమునందున్న పరమ పురుషుడు ఉపద్రష్ట (సాక్షి), అనుమంత, భర్త, భోక్త, మహేశ్వరుడు, మరియు పరమాత్మ అని కూడా చెప్పబడును.
modern_commentary: This verse gives a multi-faceted description of the true Self (Paramatma) that dwells within the body. It is the silent 'spectator' or witness of all our thoughts and actions. It is the 'permitter,' allowing nature to function. It is the 'supporter,' sustaining our existence. It is the ultimate 'enjoyer' of all experiences. Recognizing this higher Self within helps us disidentify from our limited ego and connect with our true, powerful nature.

sanskrit: सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसंभवाः। निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम्॥
transliteration: sattvaṁ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṁbhavāḥ | nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam ||
translation_sivananda: Sattva, Rajas and Tamas—these qualities, O mighty-armed Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body the indestructible, embodied Self!
translation_telugu: ఓ మహాబాహో! సత్త్వము, రజస్సు, తమస్సు అనే ఈ గుణాలు ప్రకృతి నుండి పుట్టినవి. అవి నాశరహితుడైన ఆత్మను శరీరంలో బంధిస్తాయి.
modern_commentary: This verse introduces the profound concept of the three Gunas—the fundamental qualities or energies of nature that shape our entire experience. Sattva (purity, harmony), Rajas (passion, activity), and Tamas (inertia, darkness) are the forces that bind our eternal consciousness to the physical body and its experiences. Understanding these three qualities is the key to understanding our own moods, behaviors, and the world around us.

sanskrit: मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवते। स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान्ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते॥
transliteration: māṁ ca yo'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate | sa guṇānsamatītyaitānbrahmabhūyāya kalpate ||
translation_sivananda: He who serves Me with unswerving devotion, he, crossing beyond the qualities, is fit for becoming Brahman.
translation_telugu: ఎవరైతే నన్ను అచంచలమైన భక్తియోగముతో సేవించెదరో, వారు ఈ గుణములను దాటి బ్రహ్మము అగుటకు యోగ్యులగుదురు.
modern_commentary: This verse offers the way to go beyond the influence of the three Gunas (Sattva, Rajas, Tamas). The key is unswerving devotion (Bhakti Yoga). By focusing the mind and heart on a higher ideal with unwavering consistency, one can transcend the pull of these natural qualities and attain a state of spiritual liberation, becoming one with the ultimate reality (Brahman).

sanskrit: निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः। द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसंज्ञैर्गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत्॥
transliteration: nirmānamohā jitasaṅgadoṣā adhyātmanityā vinivṛttakāmāḥ | dvandvairvimuktāḥ sukhaduḥkhasaṁjñairgacchantyamūḍhāḥ padamavyayaṁ tat ||
translation_sivananda: Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely retired, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, the undeluded go to that eternal goal.
translation_telugu: గర్వము, మోహము లేనివారు, సంగదోషమును జయించినవారు, నిరంతరం ఆత్మయందు నివసించువారు, కోరికలను పూర్తిగా త్యజించినవారు, సుఖదుఃఖాలనే ద్వంద్వముల నుండి విముక్తులైనవారు, అట్టి జ్ఞానులు ఆ శాశ్వతమైన పదమును పొందెదరు.
modern_commentary: This verse describes the qualities of those who attain the ultimate, eternal state of freedom. They are free from pride and delusion, have conquered attachment, are constantly focused on their spiritual identity, have overcome selfish desires, and are liberated from the dualities of pleasure and pain. This provides a clear checklist of the inner work required to achieve spiritual liberation.

sanskrit: ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः। मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति॥
transliteration: mamaivāṁśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ | manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati ||
translation_sivananda: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses with the mind for the sixth, abiding in Nature.
translation_telugu: జీవలోకంలో నా యొక్క శాశ్వతమైన అంశమే జీవుడై, ప్రకృతి యందున్న మనస్సుతో కూడిన ఆరు ఇంద్రియములను ఆకర్షించుచున్నది.
modern_commentary: This verse explains our fundamental connection to the divine. It states that every living soul is an eternal fragment of the one supreme consciousness. This divine spark, when embodied, draws the five senses and the mind towards itself, getting engaged with the material world. It is a beautiful reminder that despite our apparent separation, our essential nature is divine and we are all part of a greater whole.

sanskrit: सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च। वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम्॥
transliteration: sarvasya cāhaṁ hṛdi sanniviṣṭo mattaḥ smṛtirjñānamapohanaṁ ca | vedaiśca sarvairahameva vedyo vedāntakṛdvedavideva cāham ||
translation_sivananda: And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me are memory, knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily that which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta, and the knower of the Vedas am I.
translation_telugu: నేను అందరి హృదయముల యందు నివసించియున్నాను. నా నుండియే స్మృతి, జ్ఞానము, మరియు వాటి లోపము కలుగును. సర్వ వేదములచే తెలియదగినవాడను నేనే. వేదాంతమును రచించినవాడను, వేదములను తెలిసినవాడను నేనే.
modern_commentary: This verse identifies the divine consciousness as the source of all our mental faculties. It resides within the 'heart' or core of every being, and from it arise our memory, our knowledge, and even our forgetfulness. It is the ultimate source and goal of all wisdom. This suggests that the capacity for knowing is a divine gift present within each of us.

sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिर्ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः | दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम् ||
transliteration: śrībhagavānuvāca | abhayaṁ sattvasaṁśuddhirjñānayogavyavasthitiḥ | dānaṁ damaśca yajñaśca svādhyāyastapa ārjavam ||
translation_sivananda: The Blessed Lord said: Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and Yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity and straightforwardness,
translation_telugu: శ్రీభగవానుడు పలికెను: భయము లేకుండుట, హృదయ శుద్ధి, జ్ఞానయోగములందు నిలకడ, దానము, ఇంద్రియ నిగ్రహము, యజ్ఞము, శాస్త్రాధ్యయనము, తపస్సు, మరియు సూటిదనము,
modern_commentary: This verse begins a list of 'divine qualities'—the virtues that characterize a person of noble, spiritual nature. The very first quality mentioned is fearlessness, followed by purity of heart, dedication to wisdom, charity, self-control, a spirit of sacrifice, self-study, austerity, and honesty. These are presented as the building blocks of a divine character.

sanskrit: त्रिविधं नरकस्येदं द्वारं नाशनमात्मनः। कामः क्रोधस्तथा लोभस्तस्मादेतत्त्रयं त्यजेत्॥
transliteration: trividhaṁ narakasyedaṁ dvāraṁ nāśanamātmanaḥ | kāmaḥ krodhastathā lobhastasmādetattrayaṁ tyajet ||
translation_sivananda: Triple is the gate of this hell, destructive of the self—lust, anger and greed; therefore, one should abandon these three.
translation_telugu: కామము, క్రోధము, మరియు లోభము—ఈ మూడు ఆత్మను నశింపజేయు నరకమునకు ద్వారములు. కావున, ఈ మూడింటిని త్యజించవలెను.
modern_commentary: This verse provides a very clear and practical warning. It identifies three specific negative qualities—lust (uncontrolled desire), anger, and greed—as the 'three gates to hell.' This is a metaphor for a life of self-inflicted suffering. These three powerful emotions cloud our judgment, lead to harmful actions, and destroy our inner peace. Therefore, the first step towards a better life is to make a conscious effort to abandon them.

sanskrit: आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः। रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकप्रियाः॥
transliteration: āyuḥsattvabalārogyasukhaprītivivardhanāḥ | rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārāḥ sāttvikapriyāḥ ||
translation_sivananda: The foods which increase life, purity, strength, health, joy and cheerfulness, which are savoury and oleaginous, substantial and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic people.
translation_telugu: ఆయుష్షు, సత్త్వము, బలము, ఆరోగ్యము, సుఖము, మరియు ప్రీతిని వృద్ధి చేయునవి, రుచికరమైనవి, స్నిగ్ధమైనవి, సారవంతమైనవి, మరియు మనోహరమైనవి అయిన ఆహారములు సాత్త్వికులకు ప్రియమైనవి.
modern_commentary: This verse connects our diet directly to our state of mind. Sattvic food—which is fresh, juicy, nourishing, and pleasant—is described as promoting not just physical health, but also mental purity, cheerfulness, and a longer life. This aligns with modern concepts of a 'clean' diet, showing that the food we eat has a profound impact on our psychological and spiritual well-being.

sanskrit: कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन। सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलं चैव स त्यागः सात्त्विको मतः॥
transliteration: kāryamityeva yatkarma niyataṁ kriyate'rjuna | saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalaṁ caiva sa tyāgaḥ sāttviko mataḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Whatever prescribed action is performed, O Arjuna, regarding it as what ought to be done, abandoning attachment and also the fruit, that abandonment is regarded as Sattvic.
translation_telugu: ఓ అర్జునా! 'ఇది చేయదగినది' అని భావించి, నియమిత కర్మను ఆసక్తిని మరియు ఫలమును విడిచి ఆచరించుటయే సాత్త్విక త్యాగమని చెప్పబడును.
modern_commentary: This verse defines the highest form of renunciation ('Tyaga'). It is not about running away from responsibilities. True, Sattvic renunciation is performing your prescribed duties simply because they 'ought to be done,' while completely abandoning attachment to the process and any desire for a specific result. It is the act of doing the right thing for the right reason, without any selfish motive.

sanskrit: यतः प्रवृत्तिर्भूतानां येन सर्वमिदं ततम्। स्वकर्मणा तमभ्यर्च्य सिद्धिं विन्दति मानवः॥
transliteration: yataḥ pravṛttirbhūtānāṁ yena sarvamidaṁ tatam | svakarmaṇā tamabhyarcya siddhiṁ vindati mānavaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: He from whom all the beings have evolved, by whom all this is pervaded, worshipping Him with his own duty, man attains perfection.
translation_telugu: ఎవని నుండి సర్వభూతములు పుట్టినవో, ఎవనిచే ఈ సర్వము వ్యాపించియున్నదో, అట్టి వానిని తన కర్మచే ఆరాధించి, మానవుడు సిద్ధిని పొందును.
modern_commentary: This verse beautifully articulates the principle of 'work is worship.' It states that you can attain perfection and worship the divine source of the universe simply by performing your own natural duty (svakarma) with dedication. Your work itself becomes the offering. This elevates any profession or role, no matter how humble, to a spiritual path, provided it is done with the right attitude of reverence and commitment.

sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वभावनियतं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्॥
transliteration: śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt | svabhāvaniyataṁ karma kurvannāpnoti kilbiṣam ||
translation_sivananda: Better is one’s own duty, though destitute of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.
translation_telugu: ఇతరుల ధర్మమును చక్కగా ఆచరించుట కంటె, గుణహీనమైనదైనను తన ధర్మమును ఆచరించుటయే శ్రేయస్కరము. తన స్వభావముచే నియమించబడిన కర్మను చేయువాడు పాపమును పొందడు.
modern_commentary: This verse is a powerful message about authenticity and finding your own unique path. It's better to follow your own natural calling or duty (Svadharma), even if you do it imperfectly, than to perfectly imitate someone else's path. In a world of social media and constant comparison, this is a reminder to be true to your own nature and responsibilities. There is peace and rightness in performing the work that is uniquely yours.

sanskrit: ईश्वरः सर्वभूतानां हृद्देशेऽर्जुन तिष्ठति। भ्रामयन्सर्वभूतानि यन्त्रारूढानि मायया॥
transliteration: īśvaraḥ sarvabhūtānāṁ hṛddeśe'rjuna tiṣṭhati | bhrāmayansarvabhūtāni yantrārūḍhāni māyayā ||
translation_sivananda: The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, causing all beings, by His illusive power, to revolve as if mounted on a machine.
translation_telugu: ఓ అర్జునా! ఈశ్వరుడు సర్వభూతముల హృదయముల యందు నివసించియున్నాడు. తన మాయచే, యంత్రముపై ఎక్కినవాని వలె సర్వభూతములను త్రిప్పుచున్నాడు.
modern_commentary: This verse presents a profound metaphysical concept. It suggests that a divine consciousness resides in the heart of every being, orchestrating the universe. We are compared to figures mounted on a machine, moved by this universal power. This can be interpreted as a call to recognize the divine spark within ourselves and others, and to understand that our lives are part of a grand, cosmic play, which can help us detach from our ego's sense of absolute control.

sanskrit: तमेव शरणं गच्छ सर्वभावेन भारत। तत्प्रसादात्परां शान्तिं स्थानं प्राप्स्यसि शाश्वतम्॥
transliteration: tameva śaraṇaṁ gaccha sarvabhāvena bhārata | tatprasādātparāṁ śāntiṁ sthānaṁ prāpsyasi śāśvatam ||
translation_sivananda: Fly unto Him for refuge with all thy being, O Arjuna; by His Grace thou shalt obtain supreme peace and the eternal abode.
translation_telugu: ఓ భరతవంశీయుడా! సర్వభావములతో ఆయననే శరణు పొందుము. ఆయన అనుగ్రహము వలన పరమ శాంతిని, శాశ్వతమైన స్థానమును పొందెదవు.
modern_commentary: Following the idea that a divine force dwells within, this verse gives the practical instruction: take refuge in that inner, higher power with your whole being. It's a call to shift our trust from our limited ego to this universal consciousness. The promise is that through this act of surrender and faith, by 'His Grace,' we will attain a profound peace and a sense of eternal security that cannot be found through our own efforts alone.

sanskrit: इति ते ज्ञानमाख्यातं गुह्याद्गुह्यतरं मया। विमृश्यैतदशेषेण यथेच्छसि तथा कुरु॥
transliteration: iti te jñānamākhyātaṁ guhyādguhyataraṁ mayā | vimṛśyaitadaśeṣeṇa yathecchasi tathā kuru ||
translation_sivananda: Thus has wisdom more secret than all secrets been declared to thee by Me; having reflected on it fully, do as thou choosest.
translation_telugu: ఈ విధముగా రహస్యముల కంటె రహస్యమైన జ్ఞానమును నేను నీకు చెప్పితిని. దీనిని పూర్తిగా విమర్శించి, నీకు నచ్చినట్లు చేయుము.
modern_commentary: This is one of the most empowering verses in the Gita, championing free will. After imparting all the profound wisdom, Krishna does not command Arjuna. He says, 'I have given you the knowledge. Now, reflect on it fully, and then do as YOU choose.' It underscores that spiritual life is not about blind obedience but about receiving wisdom, contemplating it deeply, and then making our own conscious, responsible choices.

sanskrit: मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु। मामेवैष्यसि सत्यं ते प्रतिजाने प्रियोऽसि मे॥
transliteration: manmanā bhava madbhakto madyājī māṁ namaskuru | māmevaiṣyasi satyaṁ te pratijāne priyo'si me ||
translation_sivananda: Fix thy mind on Me, be devoted to Me, sacrifice to Me, bow down to Me. Thou shalt come even to Me; truly do I promise unto thee, (for) thou art dear to Me.
translation_telugu: నీ మనస్సును నాపై నిలుపుము, నా భక్తుడవు కమ్ము, నన్నే పూజించుము, నాకు నమస్కరించుము. నీవు నన్నే పొందెదవు, ఇది నీకు నా సత్య ప్రమాణము, నీవు నాకు ప్రియుడవు.
modern_commentary: This verse summarizes the path of devotion (Bhakti Yoga) in four simple, powerful actions: constantly think of the Divine, be devoted, make your actions an offering, and approach life with humility. It is followed by a heartfelt promise, born of love: if you live this way, you will surely reach the ultimate goal. The added phrase 'for you are dear to Me' transforms it from a mere instruction into a loving assurance.

sanskrit: सर्वधर्मान्परित्यज्य मामेकं शरणं व्रज। अहं त्वा सर्वपापेभ्यो मोक्षयिष्यामि मा शुचः॥
transliteration: sarvadharmānparityajya māmekaṁ śaraṇaṁ vraja | ahaṁ tvā sarvapāpebhyo mokṣayiṣyāmi mā śucaḥ ||
translation_sivananda: Abandoning all duties, take refuge in Me alone: I will liberate thee from all sins; grieve not.
translation_telugu: సర్వ ధర్మములను విడిచి, నన్నే శరణు పొందుము. నేను నిన్ను సర్వ పాపముల నుండి విముక్తుని చేసెదను, దుఃఖించకుము.
modern_commentary: This is one of the ultimate verses of the Gita, a call for absolute surrender and faith. 'Abandoning all duties' doesn't mean becoming irresponsible; it means relinquishing the ego-driven attachment to our actions and their outcomes. It's about letting go of the burden of being the 'doer' and trusting in a higher power. It is a promise of liberation from all forms of suffering and a final, compassionate command: 'Do not grieve.'

sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | नष्टो मोहः स्मृतिर्लब्धा त्वत्प्रसादान्मयाच्युत | स्थितोऽस्मि गतसन्देहः करिष्ये वचनं तव ||
transliteration: arjuna uvāca | naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtirlabdhā tvatprasādānmayācyuta | sthito'smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṁ tava ||
translation_sivananda: Arjuna said: My delusion is destroyed, I have regained my memory through Thy grace, O Krishna. I am firm; my doubts are gone. I will act according to Thy word.
translation_telugu: అర్జునుడు పలికెను: ఓ అచ్యుతా! నీ అనుగ్రహము వలన నా మోహము నశించినది, స్మృతిని తిరిగి పొందితిని. నేను స్థిరముగా నున్నాను, నా సందేహములు తొలగిపోయినవి. నీ మాట ప్రకారము చేసెదను.
modern_commentary: This is Arjuna's final declaration, showing his complete transformation. He confirms that his delusion and confusion are gone, replaced by clarity and memory of his true nature and duty. This transformation, he acknowledges, happened through divine grace. He is now firm, free from doubt, and ready to act. This signifies the successful culmination of the entire teaching: wisdom leading to resolute, purposeful action.

sanskrit: यत्र योगेश्वरः कृष्णो यत्र पार्थो धनुर्धरः। तत्र श्रीर्विजयो भूतिर्ध्रुवा नीतिर्मतिर्मम॥
transliteration: yatra yogeśvaraḥ kṛṣṇo yatra pārtho dhanurdharaḥ | tatra śrīrvijayo bhūtirdhruvā nītirmatirmama ||
translation_sivananda: Wherever is Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, wherever is Arjuna, the wielder of the bow, there are prosperity, victory, expansion and sound policy; such is my firm belief.
translation_telugu: ఎక్కడ యోగేశ్వరుడైన కృష్ణుడు ఉండునో, ఎక్కడ ధనుర్ధారియైన అర్జునుడు ఉండునో, అక్కడ సంపద, విజయము, ఐశ్వర్యము, మరియు ధృవమైన నీతి ఉండునని నా నిశ్చితాభిప్రాయము.
modern_commentary: This is the final verse of the Bhagavad Gita, a concluding statement of profound optimism. It declares that victory, prosperity, and justice are guaranteed wherever there is a perfect union of Divine Wisdom (Krishna, the Lord of Yoga) and dedicated Human Action (Arjuna, the archer). Success in any endeavor is the result of aligning our skillful, focused efforts with a higher, righteous purpose. It is the ultimate formula for a successful and meaningful life.
